keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, especially in developing nations.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years, with 90% of deaths occurring in developing countries.

While global monitoring has improved—number of countries with multi-hazard early warning systems increased from 52 to 108—the situation remains dire, with half of 62 assessed countries having only basic capacity and 16% having less than basic capacity.
The situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and standardized alerts.
Early warning systems enable early action, and the WMO's goal is not just to warn but to empower communities to respond.
A notable real-world example is the evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten in May 2025, after scientists monitored a mountain glacier and predicted its collapse.
Permafrost melt is expected to increase glacier collapses and rockfalls, making early warnings increasingly vital.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The United Nations' World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has issued a global call to action to address critical gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather events, stressing that nearly half of all countries lack sufficient infrastructure to protect their populations. With over 2 million deaths linked to weather, water, and climate-related disasters in the past 50 years—mostly in developing nations—the urgency is amplified. Despite progress in early warning adoption, 50% of assessed countries still have only basic systems, and the situation is worst in conflict-affected areas. Real-world examples, such as the evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten after a predicted glacier collapse in May 2025, demonstrate the life-saving potential of early monitoring and warnings. The WMO emphasizes that early warnings are not just alerts, but tools for empowering communities to act proactively in the face of increasingly severe climate impacts.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
